message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and physical examination suggest Greater trochanteric pain syndrome. This condition involves tendons and muscles attached to the greater trochanter of the femur, causing pain in the lateral hip and thigh area. The other options do not fit the patient's presentation and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and signs are consistent with greater trochanteric pain syndrome, which is characterized by pain at the lateral aspect of the hip that is aggravated by activities such as climbing stairs or lying on the affected side. X-ray shows no abnormalities, which rules out osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The symptoms are not consistent with lumbosacral radiculopathy or iliotibial band syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh and pain aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side, suggest Greater trochanteric pain syndrome. The positive test of abducting the extended right leg against the physician's resistance also supports this diagnosis. Iliotibial band syndrome may cause lateral hip pain but does not cause tenderness to palpation. Lumbosacral radiculopathy may cause pain radiating to the leg but does not present with tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the thigh. Osteonecrosis of the femoral head presents with a gradual onset of hip pain and is more common in patients with a history of steroid use, alcoholism, or sickle cell disease, but is less likely in this patient as the X-ray of the pelvis is normal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain location, radiation pattern, and reproduction with hip abduction suggest greater trochanteric pain syndrome. Iliotibial band syndrome would present with lateral knee pain, while lumbosacral radiculopathy would have back pain and neurological deficits. Osteonecrosis of femoral head would show changes on the x-ray. The patient’s medication history is not relevant to the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pain that presents at the lateral side of the hip and radiating towards the thigh, aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side, and reproduces with abducting the extended right leg against resistance suggests Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome. All other options have different symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest greater trochanteric pain syndrome, which is characterized by pain in the lateral hip and thigh aggravated by physical activity. The tenderness to palpation over the upper lateral part of the right thigh and reproducing the pain by abducting the extended right leg against the physician's resistance further supports this diagnosis. The lack of swelling and normal x-ray results make options C and D less likely. Iliotibial band syndrome typically presents with pain on the lateral aspect of the knee and is not usually aggravated by lying on the affected side.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including tenderness over the upper lateral part of the right thigh and pain aggravated while climbing stairs or lying on the right side, are consistent with greater trochanteric pain syndrome. The positive test of abducting the extended right leg against resistance also supports this diagnosis. The other options (iliotibial band syndrome, lumbosacral radiculopathy, and osteonecrosis of femoral head) are less likely based on the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms fit the criteria for greater trochanteric pain syndrome, which is characterized by peri-trochanteric pain aggravated by hip adduction and internal rotation. Iliotibial band syndrome may also cause lateral hip pain, but it primarily affects runners and may cause swelling and inflammation along the iliotibial band. Lumbosacral radiculopathy may cause lower back pain and leg pain, but it does not usually present with hip pain. Osteonecrosis of the femoral head may cause hip pain, but it usually presents in older adults, and x-ray findings are often abnormal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Greater trochanteric pain syndrome, which is characterized by pain in the lateral hip region aggravated by activities like walking, stair climbing, and sleeping on the affected side. The x-ray of the pelvis shows no abnormalities, which rules out osteonecrosis of femoral head. Lumbosacral radiculopathy may cause pain, but there are no findings suggestive of nerve involvement in the examination. Iliotibial band syndrome usually causes pain on the lateral aspect of the knee, rather than the hip.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest greater trochanteric pain syndrome, which is characterized by pain and tenderness over the lateral hip and thigh. It is common in middle-aged women and can be worsened by activities such as climbing stairs or lying on the affected side, which matches the patient’s complaints. The other options are less likely as they do not exhibit the same specific symptoms and physical exam findings.
